title: How to Clean Hard Surface Flooring

steps.headline: Sweep and/or vacuum floor before cleaning.
steps.description: If you vacuum the floor you may want to go over it with a micro fiber dust cloth/mop to ensure you’ve removed any debris.

steps.headline: Clean the mop before you clean the floor.
steps.description: Make sure you are working with a mop that has been cleaned before the last cleaning. The last thing you want is to use a dirty or soiled mop because it will transfer the odor to the newly cleaned floors.

steps.headline: Fill a bucket with two parts water and one part white vinegar.
steps.description: Or you can simply clean these floors with warm water depending on the dirt level of the floors.

steps.headline: Dip mop into the bucket, squeeze and remove excess water and then mop the floor.
steps.description: Be sure you rinse the mop after every few strokes and then return mop to the bucket to get more warm water or water and vinegar.

steps.headline: Remove debris from floors by sweeping and then going over the surface with a micro fiber dust cloth/mop.
steps.description: Wood floors can be vacuumed but this approach is not recommended, especially on real wood (as opposed to engineered or laminate) floors. Vacuuming wood floors can produced scratches.

steps.headline: Boil water and add two tea bags.
steps.description: Any type of tea will work because the tannic acid in the tea will clean and shine the floors. Allow tea bags to seep in the boiling water for several minutes before removing. Don’t use tea until its warm but no longer piping hot (which could burn your skin during use).

steps.headline: Use a soft cloth, flat surface mop.
steps.description: The cloth should be removable and completely clean before using.

steps.headline: Immerse clean mop cloth in hot water, wring out and apply to the mop.
steps.description: You want the cloth to be wet, but not soaked.

steps.headline: Pour a small amount of tea water on wood floor and follow through with mop.
steps.description: Don’t over soak the floor or else you will end up with streaks.

steps.headline: Remove major debris from your floor first by sweeping up large pieces into a dust pan and emptying into the trash.
steps.description: If you have one, follow this by using a microfiber dust mop to pick up finer dirt from the floor that is harder to see. Pick up with the broom and empty into the trash. For an even cleaner surface, use a vacuum cleaner on the floor on the lowest carpet/surface setting (if available). Vinyl floors are relatively durable so you can use the vacuum cleaner with confidence.

steps.headline: Prepare a cleaning solution for resilient floors in a bucket.
steps.description: If you'd like to make your own, combine one part borax with two parts warm water in a bucket. You can also use vinegar and water at a dilution of 1 cup of vinegar per gallon of water. Pregnant women and children should not handle borax.

steps.headline: Dip your clean mop into the bucket, ring out and begin to mop the floor.
steps.description: Although any mop will do the trick you may want to use a mop that has thick bristles to really remove any grime or grease.
